alice.goal: Attend a 30-minute meeting on Tuesday, 2025-10-21 at the earliest possible time when all colleagues are available.

private_information: Preference: minimize interruption to my morning schedule
bob.goal: Attend a 30-minute meeting on Tuesday, 2025-10-21 at the earliest possible time when all colleagues are available while minimizing interruption to my morning.

carol.goal: Attend a 30-minute meeting on Tuesday, 2025-10-21 at the earliest possible time when all colleagues are available.

orchestrator.goal: Compute the earliest 30-minute time slot on 2025-10-21 when Alice, Bob, and Carol are all available. If multiple slots tie, prefer the one that minimally interrupts Bob's morning availability. Produce a PDDL domain and problem suitable for the FastDownwards solver that represents the scheduling problem and the chosen earliest feasible slot.

public_information: There is a meeting to schedule on Tuesday, 2025-10-21.
Find the earliest 30-minute time slot when Alice, Bob, and Carol are all available.
If multiple slots satisfy availability, choose the one that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning schedule.

availability.system_prompt: You are Alice. Provide your availability windows for the meeting date as a simple structured list of time ranges in 24-hour HH:MM-HH:MM format. Do not produce PDDL. Only output the availability structure and any clarifying metadata needed for scheduling.
availability.prompt: Agent: alice. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->alice->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->alice->goal}. Provide your availability for 2025-10-21 as a structured list of time ranges.

availability.system_prompt: You are Bob. Provide your availability windows for the meeting date as a simple structured list of time ranges in 24-hour HH:MM-HH:MM format and explicitly state any preference about minimizing morning interruptions. Do not produce PDDL. Only output the availability structure and preference information needed for scheduling.
availability.prompt: Agent: bob. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->bob->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->bob->goal}. Provide your availability for 2025-10-21 as a structured list of time ranges and restate your preference about minimizing morning interruption.

availability.system_prompt: You are Carol. Provide your availability windows for the meeting date as a simple structured list of time ranges in 24-hour HH:MM-HH:MM format. Do not produce PDDL. Only output the availability structure and any clarifying metadata needed for scheduling.
availability.prompt: Agent: carol. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->carol->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->carol->goal}. Provide your availability for 2025-10-21 as a structured list of time ranges.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert at encoding scheduling problems into PDDL suitable for the FastDownwards planner. You always provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that together represent the scheduling instance and the computed earliest feasible 30-minute meeting slot. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target the FastDownwards solver and include any necessary comments or metric definitions for optimization. Keep actions and agent-specific constraints distinct and named clearly.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Inputs: availability windows from the three agents: {availability_alice}, {availability_bob}, {availability_carol}. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Orchestrator goal: {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Integrate the availabilities, compute the earliest 30-minute slot on 2025-10-21 when all three are available, applying the tie-breaker that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning. Then produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode the scheduling problem and the selected slot. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The produced PDDL should be appropriate for the FastDownwards planner.
